page.title: 05St Mary's, Shenley
page.content: St Mary's stands on a slight rise. The earliest part is the chancel dating from Norman times. The tower, situated in the middle of the church, has an octagonal staircase. Housed in the tower is the clock & 6 bells. In 1908 the bells with the exception of the 600 year old tenor were recast. 3 of the chancel windows are Norman with chevron moulding. Large windows above the communion table depict the life of Christ. Under the communion table is the gravestone of the Revd. Richard Edmunds, rector who died in 1605 aged 82. The pulpit is oak, the font of sculptured stone with a carved cover, in memory of John Morris, church warden 1868 to 1899. Fine corels composed of clustered shafts with rich capitals still remain but the roof they once supported has gone.
